ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Best writing course I have ever taken. Best coourse of the semester. Professor very responsive and worked diligently to help students improve.

This course is valuable to anyone who wants to figure out how to communicate a complex idea to the general public in a popular article. This sounds like it would be easy, but it's not. Fred is an excellent, caring, considerate, and thoughtful professor. You are lucky if you can can get into this course because you will learn a lot and get as much attention as you need from Fred.

This class did an excellent job of walking students through the different components of an environmentalarticle and how to edit and refine those pieces into a coherent story. I really appreciated both the individual feedback from the professor and group discussions with students. The class made me think more about writing than any other class since high school! I often feel that professors require papers without explaining the key components or writing style needed for the piece. Although this course was not focused on academic writing, I think the general lessons could be applied to any environmental writing. I also look forward to applying the skills learned in this class to my blog and other writing efforts.

I think that this was an excellent class taught by an enthusiastic and encouraging professor, but I often felt trapped by my own confusion over what I wanted to write and what outcomes I wanted to produce. I know that writing is a process and much of what I learned I will recognize more in retrospect than I do now.
Overall the course, instructor and feedback on work was phenomenal and I will recommend it heartily to any and all students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Fred is a wonderful teacher - enthusiastic and interested in every single one of his students' work. He goes over every piece of writing you do in incredible detail. I learnt a lot!It's good how we divided into teams late in the semester to review each other's work in more detail. You get great feedback on your own work and you learn from your peers' work.
Personal interactions with the professor. Comments from from professor and fellows students. Access to a wide range of wonderful writing examples.

The enthusiasm and commitment of the instructor is second to none in all my years of education.you have to practice writing if you want to write- and you have to read great works if you want to write great works. this class provides that.

Going through the assigned articles and learning how great writers communicated their chosen messages. Also, getting feedback from Fred on my writing was a wonderful experience that I've never had before. If there were a next level of this course, I would take it.

The level of detail put into feedback from both the students and the professors was beyond impressive and extremely helpful.The readings were on target and offered great examples for students to follow, regardless of each student's writing style or topic. It was very helpful to have a comprehensive guide to signature environmental writing pieces upon which to draw inspiration from.The dinner purchased for students helped ease the difficulty of taking a class 6:39 - 9:30pm, it made it easier to focus and facilitated energy for engaged discussions.
Learning the basic components of a non-academic article and practicing what you've learned by writing about your own experiences/research
The amazingly detailed feedback from the professor on individual writing projects.
The instructor, Prof Strebeigh is phenomenal !!
Readings, class discussions, and class feedback on working drafts.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Can't think of anything

Perhaps a slight tweaking of the design of lecture- the professor is interested in drawing out specific answers from students and guides us towards the answer, which can get unwieldy if we're not going in the direction he's thinking about.
I would have liked to spend some more time of crafting an angle for the article. We wrote multiple pieces, which had varying angles for me, and as a result I really struggled to put it all together.

Overall, I thought the class was comprehensive and thorough. I think I would have appreciated more one-on-one feedback from the professor or one more additional editing round to polish the final piece. The beginning of the course certainly entailed the most work, but it worked well with the course's structure and having a strong platform for building a final piece.
None

The group work toward the end of the semester was fairly loosely organized. My group worked well together, but did not take advantage of peer reviewing outside of what was required for the course. I think it would be valuable to encourage more peer review if it can be done without taxing the process of writing itself.
I think it's as good as it can get!
I honestly can't think of a way to improve this course...

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA
N/A
Course lectures are basically all interactive discussions that are extremely effective and valuable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course fits with any program because it teaches you an essential skill: writing.
Advance my writing.
communication. is. critical.
Learning how to be an effective communicator is what conservation of the environment is all about. If you can't communicate, you won't make any progress.

One of the biggest challenges for academics is translating complicated ideas into something intelligible to the general public. I try to accomplish this through my blog and Sage Writing, but I have never had formal training in writing for a general public on scientific classes. This class was perfect for filling that gap.
This course helps students learn how to communicate what they've learned from their research or classes to a broader audience in an interesting and inviting way.

Writing is an essential skill regardless of discipline. I don't necessarily see myself going into the field of environmental writing, but I have confidence that my writing has improved and it will continue to improve. This course helped me to become more cognizant of my grammatical mistakes and equipped me with an understanding of the various formulas (and anti-formulas) for environmental writing.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to get better at writing and learn how excellent writers write so excellently.
Interest.
Because there are almost no environmental humanities here at yale and its a fucking tragedy. Plus writing is awesome! and so is Fred!
I wanted to improve my writing skills. I not only did that, and gained confidence in my abilities, but I also got the chance to develop a new solution/idea to a really complex problem.
I took this course to learn more about non-academic writing.
To work on my own material and to improve my writing.
I'm interested in environmental journalism and I enjoy writing and so I thought this course would help me become a better writer.
A chance to improve my writing and conduct research on a topic I've wanted to write about for years.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Absolutely!
yes.
Yes. This is an excellent course and Fred is an excellent professor.
Yes, and they went beyond my expectations by including a very detailed analysis of my writing style, word choices, and voice.
Absolutely.

I think that the teaching and feedback met my expectations. This is also a course that demands that you meet your own expectations, in terms of producing a publishing quality article. I cannot say that I have met those expectations quite yet.
Absolutely !
The knowledge I gained from the course exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Really helpful. You get great feedback on your own work and you learn from your peers' work.
Very helpful comment on my writing from the group.
Group editing- good to hear what people see and what jumps out.
It is great to have a group of people, interested in similar topics to yours, give you feedback on your work.

The group work was great for receiving personalized feedback from a group of students working on similarly themed papers. It was helpful to learn from my peers, although it was sometimes challenging to synthesize all of the individual edits into my paper. It was much more useful for clarifying complex ideas/sentences and improving the general message or themes of the piece.
Working in a group allowed me to receive a greater amount of feedback and support.
Great feedback from peers, but I don't think we took full advantage of each other as a resource. I think it would be useful to assemble peer review groups earlier in the semester.
Small groups really helped and the input from all the team members was valuable.
Work groups in this class are revising teams for the second half of the term and gave us a chance to get a lot of directed feedback from our peers as well as the professor.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it! Put a lot of effort in and you'll reap the rewards.
Do it. Make sure you propose a topic you truly love, and even more importantly, know a ton about.

Be upfront and honest with Fred. If you're frustrated, tell him, he will give you upfront and honest feedback which is invaluable. I waited until later in the semester to do this which left me frustrated, alone, and thinking about dropping the class for a few weeks in the middle of the semester.
Know what you want to write about and the angle you think you should take to entice a broader audience.

Go to Fred's informational meeting in the spring semester or contact him before you leave to do you summer research. Field research is often structured very differently from journalistic research; his advice will help you to balance the needs and goals of both.
Take it!!! It's a lot of work but you will become a better writer!
If there is something you want to write about, don't miss the opportunity to take this class!
